body: since toxcore places the responsibility to ensure the data does not get lost on the user (programmer), this can be seen as backwards compatible. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/TokTok/c-toxcore/2384)

comment_data.body: Is there a reason why it can't be (at least) the same as lossless packet size?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@
 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE GROUP_MAX_MESSAGE_LENGTH
 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_RAW_SIZE (MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE + GC_MESSAGE_PSEUDO_ID_SIZE)
 #define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSLESS_PACKET_SIZE 1373
-#define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE MAX_GC_PACKET_CHUNK_SIZE
+#define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE 1000

comment_data.body: there is no reason. In theory it could be even larger, if the network supports jumbo frames.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@
 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE GROUP_MAX_MESSAGE_LENGTH
 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_RAW_SIZE (MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE + GC_MESSAGE_PSEUDO_ID_SIZE)
 #define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSLESS_PACKET_SIZE 1373
-#define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE MAX_GC_PACKET_CHUNK_SIZE
+#define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE 1000

comment_data.body: It can't be much larger, because it won't fit into the next layer of tox packets. There are reasons for these numbers. Ideally we'd compute the numbers from a single MTU we set for tox packets, and everything else is derived from that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_RAW_SIZE (MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE + GC_MESSAGE_PSEUDO_ID_SIZE)

-#define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE MAX_GC_PACKET_CHUNK_SIZE
+#define MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE 1000

comment_data.body:
yea.

should i define `MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSY_PACKET_SIZE` in terms of `MAX_GC_CUSTOM_LOSSLESS_PACKET_SIZE` or by the number directly?

comment_data.body: Keep in mind that lossless "packets" are split internally into packets sized 500. so the naming is a bit conflicting.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@
 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE GROUP_MAX_MESSAGE_LENGTH
 #define MAX_GC_MESSAGE_RAW_SIZE (MAX_GC_MESSAGE_SIZE + GC_MESSAGE_PSEUDO_ID_SIZE)

comment_data.body: The if/else branches are almost identical except for 1 component of the expression. You could use ?: to shorten it and make it clearer that the branches are mostly the same.
I'd use ?: in the assert here.

Avoid copy/pasting code. If you find yourself using copy and paste commands, think twice. At this point I think ?: isn't even the right answer, but instead make a function that returns the max size for a packet type.
Is this code unreachable because we check earlier? If not, can you write a test that covers this?
it became a function, this comment is now misaligned
Thoughts on making it a single `?:` return rather than if/else return?
I like it more explicit. The compiler wouldn't care. It's also no code duplication. Depending on how we handle pkg sizes in the future, this might be an insert point...
Should it be a switch case then? (Also beware of yagni)
hmmmm, but a switch feels excessive too. man, im kinda split on this.
Let's leave it like this for now.

comment_regular_data.body:
1. this is a draft, to get my point across :)
2. lossless packets are split into parts of 500
3. the point: during filetransfers for ngc experimentation i discovered that my home network equipment did not like the spam of small packets at all, it stayed in low power mode, and only woke up when i started a tcp download simultaneously or **increased toxcores packet size**
1000 here is just and arbitrary number that was large enough for me. It made filetransfers 2x faster.
i cant imagine being the only one that is going to come across this issue. besides, larger payload means less overhead per transmitted byte :)

quote from https://www.libtorrent.org/utp.html

> The other approach of picking a very conservative packet size, that would be very unlikely to get fragmented has the following drawbacks:
> 1.    People on good, normal, networks will be penalized with a small packet size. Both in terms of router load but also bandwidth waste.
> 2.    Software routers are typically not limited by the number of bytes they can route, but the number of packets. Small packets means more of them, and more load on software routers.
